awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Validation of Constitutive and Numerical Modeling Techniques for Soil Liquefaction Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Soil liquefaction is a pervasive problem during earthquakes that has caused significant and costly damage to civil infrastructure in the US and other parts of the world.  Practicing engineers and academics have been using computational models and numerical simulation tools in the design and analysis of geosystems involving liquefiable soils.  These tools are highly sophisticated and refined, but they often have been revised following many major past earthquakes to incorporate the lessons learned from post-event observations and investigations.  Thus, the validity of these tools is yet to be fully established.  The Liquefaction Experiments and Analysis Projects (LEAP) is an international collaboratory to produce a set of high quality experimental data using centrifuge testing, and then to use these data to establish the validity and range of applicability of existing computational models and simulation procedures for soil liquefaction analysis.  The collaboratory includes centrifuge facilities at the University of California at Davis, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Cambridge University (UK), Kyoto University (Japan), NCU (Taiwan), Zhejiang University (China), IFSTTAR (France), KAIST and KWater (Korea), and HKUST (Hong Kong).  The project leverages the experimental resources at these facilities to complement the testing capabilities in the participating US institutions for investigating a number of challenging problems in which soil liquefaction plays a prominent role.

Three consecutive projects (LEAP-2017, -2018, and -2019) are planned which will be used to address three important issues: reproducibility and uncertainty; effects of soil fabric; and effects of biaxial ground motion on soil liquefaction.  LEAP-2017 will use improved quality control measures to minimize uncertainties, and an extensive testing program will be designed and conducted to characterize the sensitivity and uncertainty for relatively simple lateral spreading centrifuge tests.   LEAP-2018 will produce high quality centrifuge data to enable the assessment of the applicability of computational tools for predicting the influence of fabric and layering.  LEAP-2019 will assess the performance of numerical tools against a series of biaxial shaking centrifuge experiments using synthetic and real earthquake motions.  Following each LEAP, a workshop will be held to discuss the results of experiments and numerical simulations.  The data resulting from this project will be organized, archived and publically released using a new database publication mechanism.  The organized data will be useful for (1) future validation efforts, (2) other ongoing liquefaction research, and (3) in geotechnical modeling education. A number of graduate students are involved in the project and will receive unique training opportunities beyond the capabilities of any one institution alone.  A Validation Driver Framework (VDF) will be developed to allow modelers as well as practitioners to efficiently validate their codes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The main objectives of the Liquefaction Experiments and Analysis Projects (LEAP) were to:

1. Develop high-quality experimental data on seismic response of few important geo-structural systems that contain liquefiable soils,

2. Document and disseminate the experimental data for the use of geotechnical engineers and researchers world-wide

3. Assess the capabilities and limitations of the leading constitutive and numerical modeling techniques currently used in geotechnical practice and the state-of-the-art modeling techniques through type-A (blind) and type-B predictions exercises

4. Document and disseminate the comparisons of the numerical simulations with experimental data

5. Disseminate the main findings of each project by holding international workshops.

The key research outcomes are as follows:

In each LEAP project, LEAP collaborators conducted over twenty centrifuge tests to evaluate the effects of soil density and intensity of the base excitations on the system response. This substantial number of experiments could only be conducted through international collaborations with outstanding centrifuge modeling experts from various parts of the world including the UK, France, Japan, China, South Korea, Taiwan in addition to UC Davis and RPI.

The experimental work conducted throughout these projects demonstrated repeatability when the soil density (and other critical components of the tests such as earthquake motions) were consistent.

The collective centrifuge tests allowed for establishing sensitivity and response surfaces under a broad range of earthquake motions (intensity and frequency content) and initial conditions of the soil.

During LEAP projects, researchers at each centrifuge site utilized the latest measurement techniques to improve the quality and quantity of the measured responses. Examples are the use of digital imaging correlation and particle image velocimetry for measuring displacements of soil-structure systems, tactile pressure sensors to estimate soil-structure interaction-induced stresses in critical locations within the system, in-flight Cone Penetration Testing (using the same CTP tool in all participating centrifuge facilities). GW researchers used fiber optic sensors in the element to measure typically unknown stresses in these tests.

The PIs have archived the experimental data obtained through the LEAP projects on Design-Safe. LEAP researchers have provided detailed analyses of these observations in their Mater’s theses, doctoral dissertations, proceedings of LEAP workshops, conference papers, and journal publications.

The LEAP data are available to the public. Each LEAP project re-used the data produced in previous LEAP projects. In addition to LEAP researchers, other investigators from around the world have also used the LEAP data in their research.

The large amount of experimental and numerical simulation data produced in the LEAP projects provides an excellent opportunity for other investigations to mine the data and comprehend certain aspects of soil behavior and model performance.

The numerical simulations conducted throughout the LEAP project allowed for identifying important limitations of few major constitutive models in capturing the stress-strain-strength response of liquefiable soils in element tests. So far, three participating numerical simulation teams used these observations to improve their constitutive models.


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Majid T Manzari
